DataElement.preferredName: Vaginal Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Group Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Stage group determined from information on the tumor (T), regional node (N) and metastases (M) and by grouping cases with similar prognosis for cancer of the vagina.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Relating to the vagina or to any sheath._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Relating to the vagina or to any sheath.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to the vagina.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Stage Grouping; an assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage. (caDSR)

Concepts.definition: An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage, as well as prognostic parameters for specific cancers.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per final community approval. mc 5/7/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Vaginal Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Group Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A term that refers to the staging of vaginal carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition._An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding indicating that the extent of organ/tissue involvement by a malignant neoplasm is not reported or not assessed.

Concepts.definition: The extent of organ/tissue involvement by a malignant neoplasm is not reported or not assessed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage 0 includes: Tis, N0, M0.  Tis: Carcinoma in situ (preinvasive carcinoma). N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  FIGO no longer includes stage 0. (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.definition: Stage 0 includes: Tis, N0, M0.  Tis: Carcinoma in situ (preinvasive carcinoma). N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  FIGO no longer includes stage 0. (AJCC 7th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage I includes: (T1, N0, M0).  T1: Tumor confined to vagina.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage I Vaginal Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage I includes: (T1, N0, M0).  T1: Tumor confined to vagina.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0. T2: Tumor invades paravaginal tissues but not to pelvic wall.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage II Vaginal Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0. T2: Tumor invades paravaginal tissues but not to pelvic wall.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage III includes: (T1-3, N1, M0) and (T3, N0, M0). T1: Tumor confined to vagina.  T2: Tumor invades paravaginal tissues but not to pelvic wall.  T3: Tumor extends to pelvic wall.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  N1: Pelvic or inguinal lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage III Vaginal Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage III includes: (T1-3, N1, M0) and (T3, N0, M0). T1: Tumor confined to vagina.  T2: Tumor invades paravaginal tissues but not to pelvic wall.  T3: Tumor extends to pelvic wall.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  N1: Pelvic or inguinal lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IVA includes: T4, Any N, M0. T4: Tumor invades mucosa of the bladder or rectum and/or extends beyond the true pelvis (bullous edema is not sufficient evidence to classify a tumor as T4).  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IVA Vaginal Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IVA includes: T4, Any N, M0. T4: Tumor invades mucosa of the bladder or rectum and/or extends beyond the true pelvis (bullous edema is not sufficient evidence to classify a tumor as T4).  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IVB includes: Any T, Any N, M1. M1: Distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IVB Vaginal Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IVB includes: Any T, Any N, M1. M1: Distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: No Value Exists:An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.longName: Vaginal Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
Concepts.definition: A term that refers to the staging of vaginal cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.
An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage, as well as prognostic parameters for specific cancers.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
